segments.advisor_message: So, think of investing like sailing a boat. When you’re out in the open water, the winds can change suddenly, which represents market volatility. You can't control the wind, but you can adjust your sails to navigate through it.
segments.client_message: Uh, I get that, but, um, what do you mean by 'adjusting the sails'? Like, how does that work with, um, my investments?

segments.advisor_message: Right, adjusting the sails means being adaptable. Like, if one investment isn’t performing well, you might want to, uh, shift your strategy, kinda like changing the angle of your sails depending on the wind direction.
segments.client_message: Okay, but sometimes it feels like, um, all the investments are, you know, not doing great at the same time? Does that mean I should just stop sailing altogether?

segments.advisor_message: Not at all! Just like a sailor wouldn’t quit at the first sign of a storm, in investing, timing is key. You need a solid plan, kinda like having a compass to get you through rough waters. It’s all about, um, having the right tools.
segments.client_message: I see, so it’s more about having a strategy rather than just, like, jumping in? That makes a bit more sense. Thanks.
